ESL Relation

1. Engage (The Hook) Objective: Capture students’ attention and stimulate curiosity about famous monuments. •Teacher Role: • Start with a hook activity: Show images or videos of iconic landmarks (e.g., Eiffel Tower, Pyramids of Giza, or a landmark from the students’ country) without giving them too much context. • Ask students: “What do these monuments have in common? Why are they famous around the world?” • Introduce key questions to make them think: • “What makes these landmarks stand out?” • “Why do you think people travel from all over the world to see them?” • “What do you think makes a monument stable and visually appealing?” • “Can you guess how these structures have remained standing for centuries?” •Student Role: • Participate actively by answering the questions and discussing the monuments. • Share ideas on why these landmarks are iconic (e.g., size, design, historical significance). • Think critically about the structure and design of the monuments and how they appeal to people. •Strategy: • Visual Engagement: Show striking images of famous monuments (perhaps including monuments from the students' own country to make it more relatable). • Incorporate a brief video clip: For example, a short time-lapse video showing tourists visiting the Eiffel Tower or the Pyramids of Giza, which emphasizes their cultural significance and global recognition. • Use Questions to Generate Curiosity: These thought-provoking questions help students start thinking about the importance and impact of these monuments. They are likely to have their own thoughts on why these structures are famous, helping to deepen their interest.

2. Explore
Teacher Role:
1.Introduction to Monument Design: 1. Begin by showing visual aids (images or videos) of famous monuments such as the Eiffel Tower, Pyramids of Giza, and Colosseum. 2. Prompt questions to focus on the design: 1. "What shapes do you see in these structures?" 2. "How do these shapes contribute to the monument's stability?" 3. "What makes these monuments visually appealing?" 2.Guide Students to Identify Basic Shapes: 1. Explain that every monument, no matter how complex, is made up of basic shapes. 2. Example: 1. The Eiffel Tower uses triangles and long beams (rectangular prisms). 2. The Pyramids use squares and triangles. 3. Task: Have students observe and list the basic shapes they notice in the monument images. 3.Hands-On Exploration with Shapes: 1. Provide students with materials (such as LEGO blocks, paper, or digital design tools). 2. Explain the task: "Now, it’s your turn to create a monument using only basic shapes. You can use blocks, cut out paper shapes, or try a digital design tool." 3. Guide the activity by encouraging students to focus on combining shapes (such as cubes, cylinders, and triangles) to form a structure that looks stable and balanced. 4.Discuss Balance and Symmetry: 1. Explain how symmetry (both vertical and horizontal) is essential in creating visually appealing and stable monuments. 2. Encourage students to consider how they arrange their shapes to create balance in their designs.
Student Role: 1.Observe and Identify Shapes in Famous Monuments: 1. Look at images or videos of famous monuments and identify the basic shapes used in their construction (triangles, squares, cylinders, etc.). 2. List or sketchthe shapes they observe in their notebooks or on a worksheet. 3. Collaborate with peers to discuss what shapes each monument is composed of and share findings. 2.Create Monument Designs Using Basic Shapes: 1. Use materials provided (building blocks, paper, digital tools) to create a monument of their own using the basic shapes. 1. Example: Using paper or cardboard, students might cut out triangles, squares, and circles to create a pyramid, tower, or other structure. 2. If using digital tools, students can design a monument by combining geometric shapes like cubes, cylinders, and pyramids. 3.Ensure Stability and Balance: 1. Arrange the shapes in a way that creates a stable structure. 2. Consider symmetry: Are the shapes balanced on both sides? Is the structure visually appealing?

Strategy: 1.Visual Exploration: 1. Use images, videos, or virtual tours of famous monuments to help students observe the shapes and features of iconic structures. 2. Interactive discussion: After showing the visual aids, engage the class in a conversation about how different shapes and features contribute to the monument's visual appeal and stability. 2.Hands-On Building: 1. Physical Models: Use LEGO bricks, cardboard, straws, or play-doh to let students build simple models using basic shapes. 2. Digital Tools: If available, use tools like Tinkercad or Google Drawings for students to design digital models of their monuments. 3.Balance and Symmetry Focus: 1. Model balance by showing students how some structures are more stable because of their symmetrical design (e.g., the balance in the structure of the Eiffel Tower or the symmetry of the Pyramids of Giza). 2. After creating their designs, ask students to assess their own structures: “Is your monument balanced? Does it stand on its own?”
Sample Activities for the Explore Phase: 1.Monument Shape Identification: 1. Show an image of the Eiffel Tower and ask: "What basic shapes do you see?" (Expected Answer: Triangles, beams, rectangles). Student Activity: List or draw the shapes they identify. 2.Hands-On Monument Creation: 1. Provide building blocks or cardboard shapes and ask students to build a simple monument (e.g., a small tower or pyramid) using only the shapes they identified in the previous activity. 1. Use blocks to form a stable structure that mimics a famous monument. 2. If using digital tools, have them design a monument by arranging geometric shapes in a 3D modeling tool. 3.Quick Symmetry Challenge: 1. Ask students to arrange their shapes in a symmetrical design to ensure balance. Check for stability: Does their design stand on its own, or does it tip over?
Materials Needed: •Visual aids: Images/videos of famous monuments (Eiffel Tower, Pyramids, etc.) •Building materials: LEGO bricks, wooden blocks, paper, cardboard •Digital tools (if applicable): Tinkercad, Google Drawings •Worksheets: Monument shape identification worksheet, design challenge worksheet

3. Explain
Teacher Role: 1.Introduce Architectural Design Principles: 1. Article Introduction: 1. Introduce the article "What Are the Principles of Architectural Design?" and briefly explain that it covers important design principles that architects use when designing buildings and monuments. 2. Key principles to highlight: 1. Balance: Symmetry and equilibrium in design. 2. Proportion: Correct sizing and relationship between different elements. 3. Unity: Creating harmony between different parts of the design. 4. Rhythm: The visual flow created by the repetition of elements. 5. Contrast: Using differences in size, color, texture to create visual interest. 3. Show the Video: 1. Use the video "The Importance of Proportion and Balance in Architecture" to visually demonstrate these principles through real-world examples, such as the Parthenon or other famous monuments. 2. Highlight how these principles make structures both stable and visually appealing. 2.Guide the Article Reading: 1. Pre-reading questions: 1. "What do you think balance and proportion mean in architectural design?" 2. "How do these principles apply to what we’ve learned about monuments?" 2. Allow students time to read or review the article (either as homework or in class, depending on your class structure). 3.Facilitate Discussion: 1. After reading the article and watching the video, encourage students to discuss the principles. 2. Ask guiding questions: 1. "Can you think of any monuments that use the principle of balance?" 2. "How do you see proportion being used in structures like the Eiffel Tower or the Great Wall of China?" 4.Summarize Key Concepts: 1. Help students synthesize the principles learned. Provide a brief summary of each principle on the board or in a digital presentation. 2. Example: "Balance in architecture is not just about making structures look good; it also ensures they are stable and safe."

Student Role: 1.Engage with the Article: 1. Read the article "What Are the Principles of Architectural Design?" (either individually or in groups) to understand the key principles of design. 2. As they read, students should focus on identifying each design principle mentioned in the article. 1. Activity: Highlight or take notes on the principles of balance, proportion, unity, rhythm, and contrast. 2.Watch and Analyze the Video: 1. Watch the video about the importance of balance and proportion in architecture. 2. While watching, students should: 1. Identify examples of balance and proportion in the structures shown in the video. 2. Take notes on how architects use these principles in real-world structures. 3.Discuss and Reflect: 1. Participate in a class discussion about how these principles apply to famous landmarks. 2. Share insights: "I think the Eiffel Tower uses symmetry and balance because..." 3. Compare with previous learning: Reflect on the monuments they’ve seen earlier and identify how the principles apply. 4.Create Visual Notes or Diagrams: 1. Draw simple sketches or diagrams of famous monuments, labeling where each design principle is applied. 2. Optional: Use a Venn diagram or chart to compare different monuments in terms of balance, proportion, etc.

Strategy to Make This Task Interesting: 1.Interactive Learning: 1. Active Viewing: Encourage students to take notes or answer quick questions while watching the video. For instance: "How does the video show the importance of balance in the Parthenon?" 2. Group Work: After reading the article, have students discuss in small groups the principles and how they relate to a monument they are familiar with. This encourages collaboration and deeper engagement. 2.Visual Examples: 1. Use real-world examples of iconic landmarks to illustrate how each design principle is applied. 2. Show the video for visual learners and explain key principles in a way that students can relate to what they already know about structures. 3.Hands-On Activity: 1. Design Practice: After explaining the principles, encourage students to think about how they can apply balance, proportion, and unity to their own monument designs. 2. Use simple diagrams or sketches: Students can draw their monuments and label which design principles they used. 4.Technology Integration: 1. Use a digital tool like Google Drawings or Tinkercad for students to create and modify digital models of their monuments, applying the principles they've learned.

5. Evaluate
Teacher Role: 1.Introduce the Challenge: 1. Explain the task: "Now that you’ve learned the key architectural principles, your next task is to investigate and analyze buildings or monuments that didn't follow these principles. Specifically, you’ll focus on how the lack of symmetry, proportion, or balance affected the structure." 2. Provide Examples: 1. Introduce some famous examples where architectural principles were overlooked: 1. The Leaning Tower of Pisa: A case of imbalance and proportion issues. 2. The Millennium Dome (London): Known for structural issues related to balance. 3. The Sydney Opera House: Discuss the challenges it faced in terms of proportion and balance during its construction. 2.Presentation Guidelines: 1. Explain the structure of the presentation: 1. Overview of the Building: Name, location, and purpose of the building. 2. Architectural Principles: Identify which principle(s) were violated (symmetry, proportion, balance). 3. Consequences of the Violation: How did the failure to follow these principles affect the building’s design, functionality, and stability? 4. Visuals: Include images or diagrams to show where the principles were ignored. 3.Provide Resources: 1. Suggest students use resources like online research (e.g., websites, articles, images) to find examples of buildings that failed to follow architectural principles. 2. Provide a rubric for the presentation to clarify expectations (organization, content, clarity, visuals, etc.). 4.Allow Time for Research and Creation: 1. Allocate time in class or as homework for students to conduct research, organize their findings, and prepare their presentation. 2. Allow students to choose whether they want to present using PowerPoint, Google Slides, or any other preferred format. 5.Q&A Session: 1. After students present, facilitate a Q&A sessionwhere peers can ask questions and offer feedback. This can help further deepen the understanding of how principles affect architectural design.

Student Role:
1.Research and Select a Building: 1. Identify a famous building or monument that failed to follow key architectural principles. 2. Gather relevant information and visual examples. Look for buildings that are known for issues in symmetry, proportion, or balance. 2.Create a Presentation: 1. Develop a short presentation (3-5 slides) based on the following: 1. Introduction: Brief overview of the building or monument. 2. Architectural Principles Violated: Explain how symmetry, proportion, or balance were not properly followed. 3. Consequences of Failure: Discuss the impact of these failures on the building's appearance, functionality, and overall success. 4. Visual Evidence: Include images of the building to highlight the issues and principles involved. 3.Present Findings: 1. Present the findings to the class in an organized, clear, and engaging manner. 2. Use visuals and diagrams to support the analysis and ensure a comprehensive understanding of how the violation of architectural principles affected the building.
Websites for Famous Buildings and Failures: 1.The Leaning Tower of Pisa - History and Design 1. Website: https://www.history.com/topics/landmarks/leaning-tower-of-pisa 2. An article from History.com detailing the history, design flaws, and engineering challenges of the Leaning Tower of Pisa. 2.The Sydney Opera House - Design and Challenges 1. Website: https://www.sydneyoperahouse.com/about-us/our-story.html 2. The official Sydney Opera House website offers insights into the design and the initial struggles the project faced, including issues with balance and proportion. 3.The Millennium Dome (London) - Design Issues 1. Website: https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-45323668 2. This BBC article discusses the architectural challenges and the reasons why the Millennium Dome faced criticism, including issues related to proportion and design choices. 4.The Pyramids of Giza - Stability and Proportion 1. Website: https://www.history.com/topics/ancient-history/the-egyptian-pyramids 2. This article explains the principles of symmetry, proportion, and balance used in the design of the Pyramids, providing a great example of how ancient structures adhered to these principles.

Strategy to Make This Task Interesting: 1.Use of Real-World Examples: 1. By focusing on real-world buildings that faced challenges due to architectural missteps, students can see the practical consequences of violating design principles. 2. The Leaning Tower of Pisa is a particularly interesting example, as it has become a famous tourist attraction despite its flaws. 2.Interactive Learning: 1. After the presentation, encourage an open class discussion: "Why do you think these principles were ignored in the first place? What could have been done differently?" 2. Let students debate if the buildings would still be iconic if these design flaws were corrected. 3.Creativity in Presentation: 1. Allow students to get creative with how they present their findings. They can include sketches, videos, or even 3D models (if available) to illustrate the failure of principles in a more interactive way. 4.Peer Review: 1. After each presentation, students can review and comment on their peers' work, giving feedback on what was effective and suggesting areas of improvement.
